title: Catching the Krug
statementHtml:
Doran and the Krug are playing a game on a grid consisting of (n+1)×(n+1)(n+1)×(n+1) cells whose coordinates are pairs of integers from 00 to nn, inclusive. The Krug's goal is not to be caught by Doran for as long as possible, while Doran's goal is to catch the Krug as early as possible. We say Doran caught the Krug if they stand on the same grid cell.

To play the game, the Krug and Doran take turns alternately, starting from the Krug:

The Krug's survival time is defined as the number of Doran's turns until Doran catches the Krug for the given starting cells of the players. Assuming that both players play optimally, find the Krug's survival time or report that the Krug can survive for infinite turns.
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

Each test case consists of a single line containing five integers nn, rKrK, cKcK, rDrD, and cDcD (1≤n≤1091≤n≤109, 0≤rK,cK,rD,cD≤n0≤rK,cK,rD,cD≤n, (rK,cK)≠(rD,cD)(rK,cK)≠(rD,cD)) — nn is the size of the grid, (rK,cK)(rK,cK) represents the Krug's starting cell, and (rD,cD)(rD,cD) represents Doran's starting cell.
outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output the Krug's survival time when both players play optimally. If the Krug can survive for infinite turns, print −1−1.
noteHtml:
Explanation of the first test case:

The Krug starts at (0,0)(0,0) and Doran starts at (1,1)(1,1). On the Krug's turn, she can only move to (0,0)(0,0), (0,1)(0,1), or (1,0)(1,0).

Doran, starting at (1,1)(1,1), can reach any cell on the 3×33×3 grid in a single move. Therefore, no matter where the Krug moves, Doran can always move to her cell on his first turn. The Krug's survival time is 11.

Explanation of the second test case:

The Krug starts at (1,1)(1,1) and Doran at (0,1)(0,1). To survive Doran's first turn, the Krug must move to a cell that Doran cannot reach. The only such cell is (2,1)(2,1).

After the Krug moves to (2,1)(2,1), Doran moves to (1,1)(1,1) to get closer.

Now, for her second move, the Krug must again move to a cell Doran can't reach, which is (3,1)(3,1). Doran then moves to (2,1)(2,1).

At this point, no matter where the Krug moves for her third turn, Doran can always reach her cell. It can be shown that this is an optimal strategy for both, and therefore the Krug's survival time is 33.
tutorialHtml:
We will find the lower and upper bound for the Krug's survival time with simple strategies for the Krug and Doran, and show that these bounds overlap at a single point.

Assume that $$$r_K < r_D$$$. In this case, the Krug can always run all the way to the $$$0$$$-th row before getting caught, and it takes $$$r_D$$$ time for Doran to reach the same row as the Krug. Similarly, if $$$r_K > r_D$$$, it takes $$$n - r_D$$$ time for Doran to reach the same row as Krug if the Krug runs to the $$$n$$$-th row. The same strategy can be applied column-wise too. Therefore, the lower bound of the Krug's survival time is:

$$$$$$ \max{ \begin{cases} \begin{cases} r_D, & (r_K < r_D) \\ n-r_D, & (r_K > r_D) \\ 0 & (r_K = r_D) \end{cases}\\ \begin{cases} c_D, & (c_K < c_D) \\ n-c_D, & (c_K > c_D) \\ 0 & (c_K = c_D) \end{cases}\\ \end{cases} } $$$$$$

Now assume a greedy strategy for Doran; i.e. Doran always moves to a cell that minimizes the absolute difference of row and column between Doran and the Krug. Let these differences be $$$d_r$$$ and $$$d_c$$$, respectively. Then after each pair of the Krug and Doran's moves, each of $$$d_r$$$ and $$$d_c$$$ is reduced (or remains at $$$0$$$) unless the Krug moved to the opposite direction of Doran for the respective axis. Since the Krug can make such move only until she reaches the edge of the grid of each axis (possibly not both, but does not matter), the upper bound of the Krug's survival time is also maximum of the time until Doran reaches that edge.

On a side note, the answer remains the same even if the Krug can choose only one direction to move at the beginning, or if the Krug can also move diagonally.
